newsitem.title: BELARUS: Belarus says its crude reserves are 66 mln tonnes.
newsitem.headline: Belarus says its crude reserves are 66 mln tonnes.

text.p: The former Soviet republic of Belarus has unexplored crude oil reserves of 66 million tonnes, or 481.8 million barrels, a top geologist said on Thursday.

Vladimir Bagino, chief oil geologist at the Belgeologiya production association, cited the figures at a news conference, but he did not say whether the numbers had been calculated according to Western standards.
Soviet-era standards blur distinctions on the commercial viability of tapping oil reserves.
Belarus produced about two million tonnes, or 40,000 barrels per day, last year.
Belgeologiya chief executive Vladimir Karpuk told the same conference that explored oil reserves would increase by 250,000 tonnes this year.
Belarussian annual crude oil consumption is 10-12 million tonnes (200,000-240,000 bpd).

The government has said that oil demand may drop when the giant Yamal-Europe natural gas pipeline, which runs through Belarus, is fully operational by 2010. The Belarussian section, capable of carrying about 68 billion cubic metres a year, is to be completed in 1998.
Belarus imports much oil from Russia, with which it signed a broad Union Treaty on cooperation on Wednesday.
